results.title: The Sounds of Aus: The Story of the Aussie Accent
results.creator_credit: Yael Bergman, David Swann, Lawrie Zion, Princess Pictures and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
The Australian accent has long been regarded as the most significant identifier of our cultural DNA and is arguably the most Australian thing about us. ‘The Sounds of Aus’ tells the story of the Australian accent, how it came about, how it has evolved over two hundred years of colonial and cultural history and how it is used in contemporary Australia. The accent reveals much about our identity, as individuals, as communities and as a nation. The Aussie accent has regularly been the battleground over which conflicts on identity have played out.
Presented with dry irony by raconteur John Clarke, ‘The Sounds of Aus’ debunks many common myths about the accent as we hear from a wide range of experts, from dialect coach Victoria Mielewska, phonetician Dr Felicity Cox, Oxford Dictionary editor Bruce Moore, and historians Michael Cathcart and Joy Damousi, to actors, comedians, and media performers such as; Rachel Griffiths, Bert Newton, Denise Scott, Santo Cilauro, Akmal Saleh, Max Gillies, Barry Crocker, Mary-Anne Fahey, and film director Bruce Beresford.

results.title: Enough Rope: Can I Write the Ending?
results.creator_credit: Kerry Brewster, Zapruder's Other Films and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: What would you do if you thought you were about to die? This is an inspiring and moving story of three strong women, Annie Robinson, Nadeen Kovacic and Jasmyne Russell, each confronting life’s hardest journey, and how they’ve chosen to face their cancer and its ramifications. Presented by Andrew Denton, first broadcast on ABC Television on September 10, 2007.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Kerry Brewster, Zapruder’s Other Films and Australian Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: After the Fires
results.brief_description:
After the worst fires in Canberra’s history in 2003, ABC TV gave four families small video cameras to record their lives after the fires.

Filmed by the families themselves, together with their friends, these short portraits of life in the months following this devastating event have now been edited into a moving one-hour documentary. Told from the families’ own perspective, the film captures milestones as they work towards regaining a semblance of normality in their lives.
Introduced by George Negus, this is a poignant story of paradise lost and paradise regained.

results.title: Selected works from "Bute utes: the movie"
results.brief_description:
A selection of 9 narrative works from across regional Victoria by various storytellers.
Produced by Regional Arts Victoria, ACE Connections, East Gippsland Aboriginal Arts Corporation, Robinvale Cultural Festival and Network House, The South-West Institute of TAFE and the Tarerer Gunditj Association and supported by The Regional Arts Fund, The Myer Foundation and VicHealth.

results.title: Flat is beautiful
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: Partly shot in Pixelvision and partly in Super 8 and using a combination of hand-drawn masks, animation and live action, this experimental film explores the theme of gender identity through the eyes of androgenous 11-year-old Taylor (Sammy Steel).
